text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with focaccia that's right i can't

but you know what we're getting ahead of

you have to make dough to dimple so

we're going to add one package of dry
active yeast tool bowl and then we're

of which would be some olive oil and
this is just going to be the first of

there is a lot of olive oil in this
which is just one of the reasons it's so

of course and then i'm going to dump in

we're going to give that a mix with the

if you're doing plain focaccia you don't

but not least some bread flour and then
all we need to do is grab a wooden spoon
or spatula and mix this in the bowl
until it sort of comes together into a
thick sticky dough and it becomes just
too hard to stir and at that point we're
going to dump this onto our work surface
and start the kneading process okay so
make sure your hands are very well
floured and we're going to go ahead
we're going to start kneading that dough
and it's going to be too wet and too
sticky when you start but as you do this
every time it gets too sticky too hard
to work with you'll simply give it
another dusting of flour all right not
too much just enough to knead it
generally better to have your dough a
little too sticky than a little too dry
I think that goes for most bread making
in general but especially with focaccia
and as soon as we knead it smooth and it
just starts to get a little bit elastic
and it looks something like that which
probably took about two or three minutes

so I'll do this in two additions a

all right both sides and I'll need that
in and once that's completely

just a little too soft and sticky and
once all that's been needed in and it is
soft and smooth again we will introduce
the last of the olive oil and then same

again only adding additional flour if it
gets to impossible to work with and
after about seven or eight total minutes
of kneading you should have a very soft

it should be fairly elastic if you poke

the entire surface is totally covered I
Pat that down a little bit we're going
to cover that with foil we're going to
let that rise in a warm place for about
an hour or until it doubles I do mine in
the oven the ovens off of course I might
took about an hour hour 15 minutes yours
might take two hours who knows but when
you're done it's going to look like this
next I want you to lightly oil a sheet
pan with a little bit of olive oil and
then we going to dump our dough on the
pan and then we're going to press it
down into sort of a rectangular shape
and the main purpose here is to knock
out all the air so really press it down
good and don't worry about trying to get
a perfect rectangle perfectly shaped
focaccia czar annoying so just get it
close and then we're going to cover it
loosely with plastic wrap and just let
it rest for 15 minutes so this is not

to let it sit covered for 15 or 20

guessed it more olive oil we're going to

lovingly with our fingertips and then
for by far the best part of the entire

I really don't like that term it's more
of a poke all right so you're going to
take between 1 and 5 fingers and press
them into the dough all over and we're
not
making some shallow depressions I want
full penetration
I want those fingertips going all the
way down to the pan so I'll usually do
with multiple fingers first and then
start hunting and pecking with one
finger looking for spots I missed and
not only is this pushing more olive oil
into the dough which is going to create
an even better texture but it's also
going to cook faster and more evenly
because we'll have a more efficient
transfer of heat and once we have an
absolute and complete poking of the
surface I'm going to go ahead and put
that back in the oven again the ovens
off this is just for rising and we're
going to let that proof for about 45

should just about double in size and it
should look incredibly interesting
people that don't cook don't get to see

I'm just dripping a little bit brushing

little dimples perfectly normal and
desirable and then last but not least
traditionally these are dusted with some

it is such a large grain salt it looks
like we're putting on a ton but it's
really not that much so give it a decent
sprinkling with the sea salts and then
you're going to pop that in your very
well preheated 475 degree oven for 15
minutes or until it looks like this I'm
predicting it's going to be golden brown
and incredibly gorgeous but let's not
stand around patting each other on the

while it's warm brush on just a little

incredibly tender with just a beautiful

really nice of course you can make an
